4.52.text: These people are amongst the greatest quiz players in Britain.

10.16.text: Together, they make up the Eggheads,

12.12.text: arguably the most formidable quiz team in the country.

17.36.text: Their question is, can they be beaten?

23.72.text: Welcome to Eggheads, the show where a team of five quiz Challengers

27.20.text: pit their wits against possibly the greatest quiz team in Britain.

33.24.text:
- And here you are. 
- Hello. 
- Here we are.

35.04.text: Looking pretty colourful and looking like you're ready for a game.

39.92.text: Taking on our awesome quiz champions today

45.00.text: Now, in forming this quintet, team captain Jeff has called up

48.32.text: the services of some of his oldest friends,

50.84.text: people he's quizzed with, someone he went to school with

53.60.text: and, hopeful of a music round, someone he's been in a choir with.

59.52.text: Hi, I'm Jeff and I have my own jewellery and coin business.

63.28.text: Hi, I'm Jennifer. I'm a financial assessor.

66.08.text: Hi, I'm Mike and I'm a company director.

68.60.text: Hi, I'm Ricky. I'm also a company director.

71.44.text: Hi, I'm Alan and I'm a freelance journalist and author.

74.88.text:
- So, Jeff and team, welcome. Good to see you. 
- Thank you.

78.12.text: So it's all about you, this, Jeff, isn't it, really?

80.36.text:
- It's all your friends and contacts and all that? 
- Absolutely.

83.36.text:
- I'm the one that got the team together, yeah. 
- Well done.

86.16.text: Not far away from where we're recording this.

88.60.text:
- No, very local, all of us. 
- And quizzing, tell us about that.

92.60.text: Yeah, well, we all quiz once a week but Mike, Ricky and I

96.80.text: have been quizzing for about 20 years, so not a bad pedigree.

101.40.text: What is it about quizzing that people in this country love?

104.52.text: The fun of it? I don't know. It's just... It's good fun.

107.84.text:
- So good luck. 
- Thank you. 
- I hope you have a great game.

111.44.text: Every day there is £1,000 worth of cash

113.52.text: up for grabs for our Challengers.

115.16.text: However, if they fail to defeat the Eggheads,

117.40.text: the prize-money rolls over to the next show. So, "Swots? Not!",

121.04.text: The Eggheads have won the last four games,

123.16.text: which means there's £5,000 on the table.

125.08.text:
- Would you like to play for it? 
- Yes, please. 
- Absolutely.

127.68.text: Let's go for it. The first head-to-head battle

129.92.text: is on the subject of history. Who would like history here?

133.92.text:
- Not for me. 
- Alan? 
- I'd have said Alan. You OK with that? History?

137.76.text:
- Looks like me then. 
- I think you're voted.

140.44.text: OK. Alan, choose an Egghead to go against.

147.40.text: OK, Dave, the word has got out.

149.44.text: Alan from "Swots? Not!" versus Dave from the Eggheads on History.

155.20.text: would you please both take your positions

160.20.text: So, everyone on the Challengers' team is connected through Jeff.

164.04.text: Alan, you've got to tell us how you know Jeff.

166.28.text: I sang in a choir with Jeff last year.

172.04.text: Alan, you can choose, do you want to go first or second?

179.64.text: Tremendous Knowledge Dave, your first question.

181.84.text: Which of these historical events took place in 1975?

197.04.text: The Berlin Wall, I believe, fell in 1989, I think.

202.00.text: And the end of the Vietnam War was...

206.16.text: The peace treaty was signed in '75, so it's the end of the Vietnam War.

209.16.text: Yes, it's the end of the Vietnam War. Exactly.

214.64.text: The weapon known as the bayonet,

216.28.text: as traditionally used by the British Army,

218.72.text: is often said to have been named after a city in which country?

226.28.text: Well, I think the town is probably Bayonne,

231.84.text: It indeed is France. France is right.

238.68.text: Approximately how many Allied troops landed on the beaches of Normandy

252.84.text: I don't like the look of 821 or 156.

264.64.text:
- Is it 800? 
- No, no, no, it's 156.

266.96.text:
- Oh, right. Sorry. 
- It was that big. 
- Yeah, sorry.

270.32.text: 156,000 is the answer, so a bit of an advantage to you here, Alan.

274.60.text: In which year was the statesman, inventor and writer

291.92.text: He'd be grown-up and an adult

293.44.text: by the time the War of Independence came around,

297.84.text: so I think I would put him at...

304.00.text: Well, Kevin knows his dates. Kevin?

306.20.text:
- 1706. 
- 1706 is the answer here, Alan. OK, Dave, your question.

311.36.text: One point each. Which of these men died in November 1530,

315.80.text: while travelling south to face charges of treason?

327.56.text: It's not Guy Fawkes. Now then...

333.76.text: I should be watching more Wolf Hall

335.32.text: because it had Cardinal Wolsey and different dates.

341.56.text: It's just because I don't associate

343.24.text: Cardinal Wolsey's death with that, so...

348.88.text:
- No, it's wrong. It's Cardinal Wolsey. 
- Right, OK.

353.36.text: What name is given to the short 1969 war between Honduras and El Salvador?

358.76.text: If you get this right, you're in the final, Alan.

365.40.text: Oh, yes, I remember this happened when I think there was a crowd riot

370.20.text: at a football game between the two countries

373.16.text: and it led to a brief war, so that would make it the Football War.

377.68.text: If you've got this right, you're in the final. Is he right, Dave?

380.40.text:
- Yes, of course. 
- Yes, you are right. Football War it is.

382.92.text: You knocked Dave out. Alan, you're in the final round.

387.32.text: a very handy player for your team, I suspect.

389.48.text: Please come back to us, both of you, and we'll play on.

393.00.text: This is good. "Swots? Not!" are in a good position. Lost no brains.

396.80.text: The Eggheads have lost a brain. And the next subject is Sport.

406.04.text: Company director from East Kilbride. Against which Egghead?

409.32.text: Who there looks the least sporty?

413.12.text:
- OK. 
- I'll go for Judith, please. 
- Oh, no. 
- Sorry, Judith.

418.12.text: We've had a whole series. Let me just see the face.

420.72.text:
- And I've been winning them. 
- She's been winning them.

424.04.text: So it's Mike from "Swots? Not!" versus Judith from "Sports? Not!"

429.16.text:
- Yes! 
- How we feel most of the time.

431.60.text: Please go to our Question Room now.

435.64.text: So, Mike, would you like to go first or second?

438.16.text: Can I go first, please, Jeremy?

442.92.text: By all means. Here we go.

445.28.text: In which year did John McEnroe famously shout,

456.60.text: I don't know why but 1975 was the first thought

459.88.text: that went through my mind, so going on that assumption I'm going to go

463.24.text: with the one that's nearest and I'll try 1976, please.

472.72.text: That was the one about "This place is the pits of the world."

475.92.text: It's all the same thing, SuperBrat, and all that.

482.20.text: What is the inside diameter of an NBA basketball hoop?

499.04.text: off the screen, so it's got to be 18, hasn't it?

507.20.text:
- Yep. 
- Is that what it is?

512.80.text: I just wanted to make sure cos your measurements were...unusual.

518.88.text: When Gareth Edwards scored what has been described

521.72.text: as "the try of the century" against the All Blacks

524.88.text: in January 1973, for which team was he playing?

535.80.text: I'm not too sure about this, to be honest.

543.00.text: I'm going to go for Wales based on nothing, really.

547.44.text:
- I'm just going to go down the middle this time. 
- OK.

550.36.text: Judith, do you know this one?

551.92.text: I would have said Wales too, with all that crowd support.

555.12.text: Yeah, I would have thought so, but Barbarians is the answer here, Mike.

559.92.text: So, Judith, if you get this one right, you've won on Sport.

564.68.text: The footballer Philippe Coutinho was born in which country?

574.60.text: I mean, no, sorry, it sounds Portuguese language.

577.72.text: It's a Portuguese name, so it could be Brazil or Portugal.

583.48.text: Did you say a date or anything?

600.32.text:
- Yes. 
- Well, there are quite a lot of Portuguese people in France,

604.92.text: I think, as he's called Philippe, I'm going to change tack

615.36.text: and Mike's still to score in Sport.

620.08.text: In cycling, what is the name of the garment that UCI world champions

633.44.text: I've got to tell you, Jeremy, I don't have a clue.

641.40.text: I'm going to have to guess this one again.

644.84.text: I'm going to go for Tri-tone Jersey.

646.84.text: It sounds the most logical of the three. I hope I'm right.

650.44.text: Rainbow Jersey is the answer, Mike. Sorry.

654.16.text: So, Judith, you've won through on Sport.

658.96.text: Well, you still had a question in hand so you can really chalk that up.

662.76.text: We're beginning to build something here. Well done.

666.64.text: Judith, come back and we'll play the next round.

670.96.text: OK, as it stands, "Swots? Not!" have lost a brain from the final round.

674.56.text: The Eggheads have also lost a brain. The next subject is Music.

678.40.text: Who would like this? DEEP SIGH

680.08.text:
- Is that bad? A big sigh. 
- I wish I'd maybe hung on now.

684.60.text:
- You. 
- OK. I'll take the Music round, Jeremy.

687.44.text: OK, team captain Jeff, and which Egghead would you like?

690.80.text: It can't be Dave or Judith.

692.60.text: Erm, I think I'll try Pat for Music.

697.00.text: So it's Jeff from "Swots? Not!" versus Pat from the Eggheads.

699.88.text: To ensure there's no conferring, please go to the Question Room.

704.64.text: Well, Jeff, you better tell us about the choir.

706.88.text: Yes, I've been in this choir now for ten years.

710.88.text: Big choir, there's over 100 of us, called Sounds International

717.20.text: And in the past six years,

719.16.text: we have raised close to £70,000 worth for charities.

722.88.text:
- Oh, how tremendous. You must really enjoy it as well. 
- Love it.

726.44.text:
- I love singing. 
- Music. Jeff, do you want to go first or second?

734.24.text: And here is your first question, Jeff. Good luck.

736.76.text: "For what is a man, what has he got? If not himself, then he has naught,"

741.28.text: are lines from which Frank Sinatra song?

749.24.text: Well, I'm not going to sing it but it's definitely not

752.12.text: New York, New York or Come Fly With Me.

755.12.text: That is the lyrics to the beautiful My Way.

758.12.text: It is. My Way is the right answer.

761.40.text: OK, Pat, what is the name of the central character

764.24.text: in the stage musical Me and My Girl?

771.84.text: Well, I don't know this musical very well

774.52.text: but I think I'll get there by elimination.

777.24.text: I think Bill Sikes is the bad man in Oliver.

780.92.text: Henry Higgins is the linguist and etiquette coach

788.80.text: so I think I'll have to go for Bill Snibson.

796.96.text: The Kanye West single Gold Digger

799.00.text: incorporates elements of the song I Got a Woman,

802.64.text: which was originally co-written and recorded by which artist?

809.92.text: Well, again by the process of elimination,

816.20.text: I don't think it's BB King but from seeing the movie Ray,

822.20.text: I'm sure that was one of the songs, I Got a Woman,

825.88.text: And you're absolutely right, Jeff. Ray Charles.

830.56.text: was a UK hit single for which singer in 2015?

837.48.text: Well, the least likely appears to be Prince, so I'll dismiss him.

845.60.text: I think I'll have to go for Madonna but slightly concerned here.

849.52.text: Yes, you got it right, Pat. Well done. Madonna it is.

852.28.text: Sorry you can't shake him off, Jeff. It's always difficult with Pat.

856.16.text: So here is your third question.

858.16.text: Awarded to a promising artist due to release their first album in 2015,

863.16.text: which singer-songwriter won the 2015 Critics Choice Brit Award?

875.08.text: I can honestly say I've never heard of any of the three.

881.00.text: I don't know why, if it's something I've read,

883.80.text: but the name that's jumping out at me of the three of them

890.64.text: So I'll take a guess at that.

892.64.text:
- This is James Bay, Jeff. 
- Never heard of him.

896.28.text: But Years and Years are breaking through in the same way.

900.08.text: I know that's no consolation. OK, Pat, your question to take the round,

904.08.text: what was the last opera to be written by Mozart?

922.40.text: I think the distinction of the last Mozart composition

927.32.text: is generally either the Requiem or The Magic Flute,

930.16.text: and it depends on how you look at these things.

933.00.text: I think The Marriage of Figaro and Don Giovanni

935.32.text: were during the core part of his career.

939.00.text: It must be the Magic Flute, surely.

941.68.text: Yes, I'll have to go for The Magic Flute.

943.96.text: Yes, you're right. You got all three answers correct.

946.96.text: I'm very sorry, Jeff, he's knocked you out there.

949.96.text: Pat will be in the final and, sadly, you won't.

952.56.text: Please return to us and we will play the fourth round.

957.72.text: Bad luck, Jeff. What was it that caused the trouble?

963.52.text: Cos as a choir person you've got a better handle on the...?

966.00.text:
- I love the standards. 
- The classics?

968.40.text: The classics, the standards, but anything current I'm hopeless with.

972.76.text: Your team has lost two brains.

974.60.text: The Eggheads have lost just the one brain

977.44.text: and the last subject before final is Science.

984.28.text:
- A financial assessor. And which Egghead, Lisa or Kevin? 
- Lisa.

989.32.text: I'm looking at Lisa. She's smiling. I think that's to put us off.

992.64.text:
- She's smiling winningly. You're so right. 
- Only to stop myself crying.

997.48.text: It's how we get through the day.

999.00.text: So, Jennifer from "Swots? Not!" versus Lisa.

1001.72.text: To ensure there's no conferring, please go to the Question Room now.

1006.20.text:
- OK, good luck here, Jennifer, against Lisa. 
- Thank you.

1009.48.text: And would you like to go first or second?

1017.48.text: Here we go, Lisa, your first question.

1019.84.text: Brent Crude is a trading classification

1022.28.text: of which type of fossil fuel?

1028.44.text: Oh, the off-colour jokes I could probably make and won't.

1032.28.text: I'll just go straight for oil.

1037.40.text: OK, Jennifer, which of these sea creatures

1040.24.text: is the largest member of the dolphin family?

1048.12.text: Well, I'm pretty sure it won't be killer whale,

1053.60.text: but it is a guess, so I'm going to go for manatee.

1058.68.text:
- I think it is the killer whale. 
- It's a type of dolphin, is it?

1061.44.text: Yeah, the biggest dolphin, I think. They're big fellows.

1063.92.text: Killer whale is right. SHE GASPS

1067.52.text: You got it wrong. Not manatee.

1070.20.text: OK, Lisa, pure water has a score very close to what on the pH scale?

1079.52.text: I think pure water is pH neutral or we would be suffering greatly

1084.60.text: when we drank it, so it must be 7.

1087.40.text: You're right. That's exactly where pH neutral is, so 7 is the answer.

1091.72.text: Cracking on here. Jennifer, you've got to hold back the tide.

1095.48.text: Freon is a name given to several organic compounds

1099.16.text: typically used in what type of household device?

1111.72.text: I'm pretty certain it's not a vacuum cleaner and I'm going to go...

1116.96.text: Between the other two, I'm going to go for refrigerator.

1120.12.text: Excellent, you're right. Refrigerator it is. Well done. A point to you.

1123.68.text: But, Lisa, if you get this right, you're in the final round.

1126.32.text: What name is given to animals at the top of the food chain

1129.20.text: that are not preyed upon by any other creature?

1139.56.text: So the Kevin Ashmans and the Pat Gibsons of the eating world.

1146.12.text: I think they must be Apex predators.

1148.72.text: You said the eating world, did you mean the quizzing world?

1151.64.text: Well, that's where you'd put Mr Ashman and Mr Gibson

1154.24.text:
- in the quizzing world, certainly. 
- Right, yeah.

1156.48.text: The answer is Apex predators. Well done, Lisa. Three out of three.

1159.32.text: Sorry, Jennifer, cos you let her go first

1161.80.text: she has taken the round and taken the initiative

1164.68.text: and the Eggheads may have the edge in the final, but let's see.

1168.24.text: Please, both of you, return and we'll play it.

1172.40.text: So, this is what we have been playing towards.

1174.80.text: It is time for the final round.

1178.52.text: but I'm afraid those of you who lost your head-to-heads

1180.96.text: won't be allowed to take part in this round

1182.80.text: so, Jeff, Jennifer and Mike from "Swots? Not!",

1185.76.text: and also Dave from the Eggheads,

1187.60.text: would you please now leave the studio?

1191.32.text: Well done, Ricky and Alan, for getting to this point.

1193.64.text: You're now playing to win "Swots? Not!" £5,000.

1197.20.text: Pat, Lisa, Kevin, Judith, you're playing for something

1199.96.text: that money can't buy, which is the Eggheads' precious reputation.

1204.08.text: As usual, I will ask each team three questions in turn.

1206.96.text: This time the questions are all General Knowledge

1209.28.text: and you are allowed to confer.

1212.84.text: are you able with your two brains to defeat these four?

1217.08.text: Would you like to go first or second?

1219.16.text: Well, we'll take our chances going first, Jeremy. Thank you.

1224.84.text: So, here we go and good luck to you

1228.60.text: Ricky and Alan, which of these TV soaps celebrated

1241.00.text: OK, it can't possibly be Coronation Street cos that's older.

1246.32.text: Which of these TV soaps celebrated its 30-year anniversary

1254.68.text: Definitely Emmerdale or EastEnders. I'd go for EastEnders.

1257.92.text:
- Yeah, they've had specials and so on. 
- OK, we'll go... EastEnders?

1261.56.text:
- EastEnders, yeah. 
- We'll go for EastEnders, Jeremy.

1264.44.text: EastEnders is the right answer. Well done.

1269.04.text: Which of these characters from Greek mythology was famous

1273.48.text: and is traditionally said to be the son of a muse?

1282.04.text:
- Orpheus. 
- Orpheus was famous for his musical ability, wasn't he? 
- Yeah.

1287.96.text: Whilst Achilles had musical connections, the other two,

1290.64.text: Achilles and Heracles were most famous as warriors.

1293.92.text: The one who was particularly noted for his musical skill was Orpheus.

1298.48.text: Because he played the harp, did he?

1302.24.text:
- Orpheus is the right answer. 
- Orpheus and his lute.

1308.92.text: I was willing them to get that one wrong

1311.12.text: cos I think that would have really helped.

1314.36.text: Which of the Beatles had a UK number two single in 1987

1318.44.text: with Got My Mind Set on You?

1331.40.text: Well done. Two out of two.

1333.28.text: Playing well. Eggheads, what type of clothing is a mantle?

1341.40.text:
- It's a cloak. 
- Cloak. Yep. M-A-N-T-L-E? 
- M-A-N-T-L-E.

1351.76.text: 2 - 2. Oh, I'm feeling the tension here.

1356.36.text: No-one has made a mistake in the last round so far.

1360.92.text: Get this right, you may not have to do anything else to win the money.

1364.16.text: What name is typically given to silver-coloured alloys of gold

1367.92.text: with nickel, platinum or another metal?

1376.64.text:
- Definitely not fool's gold. 
- No. 
- That's something else.

1379.84.text: So it's one of the other two.

1381.80.text: I know... I've heard of white gold, but...

1384.28.text: White gold, actually, I thought would be platinum.

1388.52.text:
- Jeremy, would you mind just repeating it, please? 
- Sure.

1391.80.text: What name is typically given to silver-coloured alloys of gold

1395.52.text: with nickel, platinum or another metal?

1399.52.text: Platinum is normally white gold, isn't it?

1403.80.text: I don't know about nickel or...

1405.44.text:
- And to be honest, I've never heard of colloidal gold. 
- No.

1408.16.text: Well, if platinum is part of white gold...

1410.84.text:
- I'd normally know platinum as white gold. 
- Yes.

1413.64.text:
- Shall we go for white gold, then? 
- White gold? 
- White gold.

1416.24.text: For better or worse, we'll go for white gold.

1421.08.text:
- Yes. 
- Richer for poorer. 
- Yes, you are right, you are right.

1424.28.text: White gold it is. Three out of three.

1427.28.text: Storming play. You just pulled it out at the right moment.

1433.04.text: Which economist wrote the influential 1958 book The Affluent Society?

1447.52.text:
- Always double check - 1958, Affluent Society? 
- Yes.

1456.88.text: OK, so, three out of three for both of you.

1460.40.text: Long line of green ticks, which means we go to Sudden Death, guys.

1464.24.text: Gets a bit harder cos I don't give you alternatives.

1467.16.text: Here we go. £5,000, we're playing for.

1469.84.text: What type of window, typically one that projects vertically from

1473.16.text: a sloping roof, takes its name from the French word meaning "to sleep"?

1478.96.text: Well, dormer, French for sleep. So got to be dormer.

1490.20.text: The Watts Riots of 1965 took place in a neighbourhood

1500.96.text: It is Los Angeles. The year I was born.

1506.12.text: Back to you, Alan and Ricky.

1507.80.text: Which London Tube station was originally called Gillespie Road?

1514.16.text: Do you know anything about London?

1516.92.text:
- I don't know, I've never heard of that. 
- Neither have I.

1527.52.text: And why would one be renamed something else?

1532.28.text: Why would one be renamed at all?

1534.88.text: I don't think something like King's Cross, St Pancras

1537.84.text: or something like that, because they're...

1544.32.text:
- The ones along the city embankments. 
- Bank?

1550.76.text:
- Yeah. 
- Could be one of them, anyway.

1554.32.text: What about something right in the middle?

1561.88.text:
- Circus, because there's more than one of them. 
- Yes, but there's...

1564.84.text:
- Oh, yeah. 
- Right in the middle like that, that's pretty central.

1570.32.text: Leicester Square? Again, right in the middle.

1576.36.text:
- We've got to pick one, Alan. 
- OK, Leicester Square, then.

1579.00.text:
- Leicester Square? 
- Or Piccadilly. What do you think?

1581.28.text:
- Shall we go for the first one I came up with? 
- OK, Piccadilly Circus.

1584.20.text: It's a complete guess - Piccadilly Circus.

1589.00.text: I mean, I spend a lot of time in London, I didn't know this one.

1591.72.text: I'm just wondering if there's any way of getting to it.

1594.24.text: Before you say it, if you know it,

1595.88.text: how many Tube stations are there, Eggs?

1598.32.text:
- About 200 and something. 
- Really? That many?

1602.40.text:
- You can get to it... 
- Lisa, help us.

1604.00.text: You can get to it if you're on the line.

1605.84.text: I used to live on the Northern Piccadilly Line and it's actually

1609.08.text: a ceramic sign still embedded into the wall of the station,

1611.96.text: so every time you go past you can see it under the standard sign.

1616.64.text: Why was it changed from Gillespie to the new name, before you say it?

1619.52.text: Now, that I couldn't tell you.

1621.24.text:
- Successful lobbying with an eye to publicity. 
- I see, OK.

1629.24.text: I suppose it would be like Fulham Broadway changes its name to Chelsea.

1632.84.text:
- Yeah, in a way, yeah. 
- Which is the nearest to Chelsea Football Club.

1635.92.text: It was essentially clever marketing by...I think it was Herbert Chapman,

1640.12.text:
- who was the great Arsenal manager of the interwar years. 
- Yeah.

1644.84.text: And it was just successful lobbying with what was then

1648.80.text: London Underground to get the name changed to advertise

1652.36.text: the fact that the stadium was nearby.

1655.16.text: So problem there for our Challengers -

1657.64.text: not the end of the contest.

1659.60.text: It's your question now and here it is.

1663.56.text: The Men Who Stare At Goats

1665.72.text: and The Psychopath Test are books by which British author?

1671.04.text:
- Jon Ronson. 
- Jon Ronson. 
- I don't know. 
- Yeah, Jon Ronson.

1673.92.text: Erm, the journalist and writer Jon Ronson.

1677.76.text: If you've got it right the contest is over.

1681.88.text: We say congratulations, Eggheads, you have won.

1690.60.text:
- Arsenal, Arsenal. 
- A toughie! 
- What can I say? What can I say?

1695.32.text:
- But well played. 
- Thank you. 
- Thank you.

1697.12.text: And thanks for coming in and playing. Commiserations to "Swots? Not!".

1700.48.text: The Eggheads have done what comes naturally to them

1702.76.text: and they reign supreme over quiz land still.

1705.40.text: It means you won't be going home with the £5,000,

1707.56.text: so the money rolls over to our next show. Eggheads, congratulations.

1711.32.text: Knowing the Arsenal thing as well, that's impressive stuff.

1714.52.text: Who will beat you, I wonder?

1715.92.text: Join us next time to see

1717.08.text: if a new team of Challengers have the brains to defeat the Eggheads.

1721.88.text: Good contest today. See you next time. Goodbye.
